Description: Fragment of solid-cast figure representing Isis nursing in copper alloy; depicted as holding her left breast with the right hand and her left arm in the attitude of supporting her son, Harpokrates (missing); wearing a tripartite wig with uraeus in front; face relatively well detailed and hair detailed with vertical incisions; Hathoric crown missing, left hand broken and broken below chest; corroded with some incrustations and burnt traces.
Findspot: Excavated/Findspot: Town (Naukratis), House of 'cache of bronzes' (probably)
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by World Museum, Liverpool. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

Several figures of Isis, including a 'bust of Isis' such as this specimen, were discovered in the cache of bronzes in a building located in the southern part of the town (Petrie 1886, 41-42). This figure could pertain to this hoard since it was discovered during the first season of excavation at Naukratis. The burnt traces on the figure support further this assertion because many finds from the cache bear such traces (Petrie 1886, 41). The cache was probably made around the late 5th-early 4th c. BC, but some bronzes from this cache could be earlier in date (Masson 2015). The figure could pertain to the very common type Isis nursing Horus, type G12 in the typology of bronzes by K. Weiss (Weiss 2012, 330-331, 822-833, Pl. 56). This type became very popular from the Late Period onwards and one of the most depicted themes in bronze statuary (for example: Grenier 2002, 51-58, pl. VIII-X; Goddio and Fabre 2008, 318-9 no. 178-180; Roeder 1956, § 303-314). Isis nursing is also a theme which is popular in other material in Naukratis (Masson forthcoming b). Grenier, J.-C. 2002, Les Bronzes du Museo Gregoriano Egizio, Vatican City. Goddio, F. and Fabre D. 2008 (eds), Egypt’s sunken treasures, Munich. Masson, A. 2015, ‘Cult and Trade. A reflexion on Egyptian metal offerings from Naukratis’, in D. Robinson and F. Goddio (eds), Thonis Heracleion in Context, Oxford Centre for Maritime Archaeology Monograph 8, Oxford, 71-88. Masson, A. forthcoming b, ‘Naukratis: Egyptian offerings in context’, in M. Bergeron and A. Masson (eds), Naukratis in Context II: Cults, Sanctuaries and Offerings. Proceedings of the Second Naukratis Project Workshop held at the British Museum, 22nd – 23rd June 2013. Roeder, G. 1956, Ägyptische Bronzefiguren, Mitteilungen aus der Ägyptischen Sammlung 6, Berlin. Weiss, K. 2012, Ägyptische Tier- und Götterbronzen aus Unterägypten: Untersuchungen zu Typus, Ikonographie und Funktion sowie der Bedeutung innerhalb der Kulturkontakte zu Griechenland, Ägypten und Altes Testament 81.
Bibliographic references: Weiss 2012 / Ägyptische Tier- und Götterbronzen aus Unterägypten : Untersuchungen zu Typus, Ikonographie und Funktion sowie der Bedeutung innerhalb der Kulturkontakte zu Griechenland (p. 908, Nr. 1509)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (MB.143) (phase 3)
Condition: Rather poor, incomplete and very corroded
Previous owner: Currently owned by: World Museum, Liverpool
